topic: Smash Your Fear of Rejection with Tiny Risks

dialog.text: How do I stop being paralyzed by the fear of rejection? I can't even ask for small things without freaking out.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: anxious, vulnerable; Intonation: rising at the end; Speed: slightly fast; Tone: urgent, nervous; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Begin with tiny risks — questions that cost almost nothing but teach you the act of asking.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: calm, reassuring; Intonation: steady, warm; Speed: measured; Tone: encouraging; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Like...what counts as tiny? I hear you, but it feels trivial.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: curious, doubtful; Intonation: tentative; Speed: moderate; Tone: hesitant; Whispering: none

dialog.text: A free sample, asking for a recipe, requesting a minute of feedback — little asks with low stakes. Each try teaches you the motion of asking and how to handle 'no.'
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: upbeat, pragmatic; Intonation: explanatory with light enthusiasm; Speed: steady; Tone: practical; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Okay, but will tiny stuff actually help me ask for something important later?
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: skeptical, hopeful; Intonation: questioning; Speed: moderate; Tone: cautious; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Absolutely. Story: I once nervously asked a barista for a free cookie sample — got a friendly 'no' and a smile. Next time I asked for a recommendation, then their name, and later a coffee meet-up. Small asks grew into bigger access because I practiced asking.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: warm, slightly amused; Intonation: narrative cadence; Speed: relaxed; Tone: reassuring storyteller; Whispering: none

dialog.text: So it's like exercising a muscle — starting tiny makes it stronger?
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: hopeful; Intonation: rising slightly; Speed: moderate; Tone: reflective; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Exactly. Think of rejection as data, not a verdict on your worth. Try a 30-day tiny-risk challenge: one small ask a day, jot the outcome and how it felt. You'll see fear shrink as your asking practice grows.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: motivating, confident; Intonation: energetic and steady; Speed: brisk but clear; Tone: inspirational; Whispering: none

dialog.text: What if a 'no' still stings? That part scares me most.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: vulnerable; Intonation: soft, concerned; Speed: slower; Tone: honest; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Acknowledge the sting, then reframe it as useful feedback. Celebrate the attempt — not just the outcome. Remember: the biggest risk is never asking, because that guarantees regret.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: empathetic, steady; Intonation: calm with conviction; Speed: measured; Tone: comforting and firm; Whispering: none

dialog.text: Try one tiny risk right after listening — say what you asked in the comments or reflect on how it felt. Share your moment so others can see how small risks build big change.
dialog.instructions: Accent: neutral; Emotional range: warm, encouraging; Intonation: upbeat call-to-action; Speed: brisk; Tone: motivating; Whispering: none
